introduction: While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:
text:
• Ancient Polynesian navigators traversed vast stretches of the Pacific Ocean.
• They used observations of stars, ocean swells, and bird flight patterns to guide their voyages.
• Voyaging canoes carried settlers across thousands of miles to islands like Hawai‘i, Rapa Nui (Easter Island), and Aotearoa (New Zealand).
• Modern experiments with traditional canoes (such as Hōkūle‘a) confirmed the effectiveness of non-instrument navigation.
• Scholars consider these feats among the most impressive in maritime history.
question: The student wants to stress how extraordinary ancient Polynesian navigation techniques were. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?
A: Ancient Polynesian navigators employed stars and ocean swells for direction when sailing to distant islands.
B: Modern replicas, like Hōkūle‘a, have confirmed that voyaging canoes are reliable on the high seas.
C: Guided by celestial and environmental cues, ancient Polynesians reached remote islands over thousands of miles, feats many scholars consider among maritime history’s most remarkable.
D: Ocean swells and bird patterns helped these navigators choose safe routes, though storms remained a challenge.
explanation: Choice C underscores the vast distances traveled using non-instrument methods and includes scholars’ view that these journeys rank among the greatest maritime accomplishments.
